Award.AbstractNarration: The Research award in the Inorganic, Bioinorganic and Organometallic Chemistry Program supports the work of Professor John E. Ellis at the University of Minnesota-Twin Cities for research into previously unexplored areas of low valent transition metal chemistry. Objectives include defining the limits of "superreduced" transition metal chemistry and providing new understanding of the reduction of coordinated ligands. Naphthalene, anthracene, and other polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon,or polyarene, complexes containing transition metals in formal oxidation states that are unprecedented, such as Sc(I-), V(II-), and Cu(I-), or very rare, such as Hf(0, II-), Ta(I, 0), and Ni(I-, II-), will be prepared by reduction of metal halides or related precursors in the presence of these hydrocarbons. The new compounds will be isolated and fully characterized whenever possible. Anionic polyarene-stabilized complexes promise to be of particular interest as unique storable sources of "naked" atomic metal anions, M(Z-). Their reactions with dinitrogen, carbon monoxide, isocyanides, phosphanes, and other acceptor ligands will be explored as a route to hitherto unknown classes of low valent metal complexes. The development of conventional routes to new hydrocarbon-stabilized metal-atom reagents will enable access of such highly-reactive species by other investigators, who do not have access to the specialized and expensive metal-vapor reactor apparatus originally required for the preparation of related species. This project is also important in the education, training, and professional development of a new generation of scientists and educators, including undergraduate and graduate students, visiting faculty, and other post-doctoral associates, where participation by minorities and women is particularly encouraged. Polyarene metal complexes are possible reagents for nitrogen fixation, catalysts for new polymers of unsaturated organic and inorganic species and precursors to novel polymetallics. This project endeavors to develop facile and reproducible routes to new labile hydrocarbon complexes and employ these species as reagents for a general investigation of the chemistry of transition metals in previously unknown or rare formal oxidation states. In this fashion significant contributions to our fundamental understanding of transition metal chemistry are anticipated.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

POR.DRECONTENT:
The award from the National Science Foundation, Chemical Synthesis Program to the University of Minnesota-Twin Cities involved research on the synthesis of hydrocarbon-stabilized metal-atom reagents with the objective of creating new and useful molecules of fundamental interest and in supporting the activities of undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral researchers in the Ellis lab. The results and knowledge were disseminated in peer-reviewed journal articles and in graduate theses. Although the official end of the grant was 01/31/2014, some key results were obtained more recently and because they do involve apparatus, chemicals and  results obtained from prior NSF funding they will be described in this Project Outcomes Report. 

The Ellis research group has been examining naphthalene and anthracene stabilized  metal complexes of vanadium, niobium, and tantalum. The tantalum results have been especially interesting and arose in part from our isolation and structural characterization of tris(naphthalene)tantalate(1-),1.

Because the naphthalene groups in this tantalate are readily displaced by a variety of small molecules, often employed in organic synthesis, it can function as a convenient source of atomic tantalum anion. An idea of the utility of this species was depicted on a cover of the journal Inorganic Chemistry (see Image). Its reactions with isocyanides, CNR, were of particular interest because they often behave like carbon monoxide. The interaction of tantalate 1 with the isocyanide CNDipp, Dipp = 2,6-diisopropylphenyl, ultimately led to an exciting result: the synthesis and characterization of the first paramagnetic isocyanide complex of a third row transition metal, hexakis(CNDipp)Ta(0). This result was very recently published in Angewandte Chemie, a premier chemistry journal for reporting important new research. An image of the X-ray structure of this substance has been included in this report. The molecule is also of considerable interest as an analog of the highly unstable hexacarbonyltantalum(0), which has only been obtained in a solid argon matrix at temperatures below 40 Kelvin. A link to this contribution is: http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/anie.201706323. 

Success in the study has really opened our eyes to the special character of the CNDipp ligand and its promise in the synthesis of important new classes of transition metal complexes, including the first pure or homoleptic isocyanides of the group 4 elements, Ti, Zr, and Hf. Wish us the best in this endeavor because we no longer have NSF funding ( for the first time in ~ 40 years!)

 

 

 


Last Modified: 08/10/2017
Modified by: John E Ellis

Images (1 of )
  • Reduction of tantalum(V) chloride by naphthalene radical anion affords labile tris(naphthalene)-tantalate(1-), which rapidly reacts with carbon monoxide at atmospheric pressure to produce hexacarbonyltantalate(1-)
    American Chemical Society
    Copyrighted
    John E Ellis
    Free and Ligand-Stabilized Atomic Metal Anions
  • Structure of hexakis(CNDipp)tantalum(0), CNDipp = 2.6- diisopropylphenylisocyanide, the first structurally authenticated Ta(0) complex to have been prepared by conventional laboratory methods
    Angewandte Chemie, J. Wiley
    John E Ellis
    Molecular Structure of Ta(CNDipp)6
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The award from the National Science Foundation, Chemical Synthesis Program to the University of Minnesota-Twin Cities involved research on the synthesis of hydrocarbon-stabilized metal-atom reagents with the objective of creating new and useful molecules of fundamental interest and in supporting the activities of undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral researchers in the Ellis lab. The results and knowledge were disseminated in peer-reviewed journal articles and in graduate theses. Although the official end of the grant was 01/31/2014, some key results were obtained more recently and because they do involve apparatus, chemicals and results obtained from prior NSF funding they will be described in this Project Outcomes Report. The Ellis research group has been examining naphthalene and anthracene stabilized metal complexes of vanadium, niobium, and tantalum. The tantalum results have been especially interesting and arose in part from our isolation and structural characterization of tris(naphthalene)tantalate(1-),1. Because the naphthalene groups in this tantalate are readily displaced by a variety of small molecules, often employed in organic synthesis, it can function as a convenient source of atomic tantalum anion. An idea of the utility of this species was depicted on a cover of the journal Inorganic Chemistry (see Image). An image of the X-ray structure of this substance has been included in this report. The molecule is also of considerable interest as an analog of the highly unstable hexacarbonyltantalum(0), which has only been obtained in a solid argon matrix at temperatures below 40 Kelvin. A link to this contribution is: http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/anie.201706323. Success in the study has really opened our eyes to the special character of the CNDipp ligand and its promise in the synthesis of important new classes of transition metal complexes, including the first pure or homoleptic isocyanides of the group 4 elements, Ti, Zr, and Hf.
